Authors:
Carina Rauen Firkowski, Marcos Ricardo Bornschein, Luiz
Fernando Ribeiro, Marcio Roberto Pie
Title:
Species delimitation, phylogeny and evolutionary demography
of co-distributed, montane frogs in the southern Brazilian Atlantic
Forest
Keywords:
Melanophryniscus, Brachycephalus, Bufonidae,
Brachycephalidae, campos de altitude, cloud forest
Abstract:
The Brazilian Atlantic Forest (BAF) is recognized as one
of the worldâ€™s biodiversity hotspots, with even more species per unit of
area than the Amazon, yet the mechanisms that led to such astonishing
diversity are yet to be fully understood. In this study, we investigate
the diversification of two co-distributed frog genera associated with
montane areas of southern BAF: Melanophryniscus (Bufonidae) and
Brachycephalus (Brachycephalidae). Species delimitation methods using
mitochondrial and nuclear loci supported the existence of a remarkable
number of highly endemic species in each genus, most of which only
present in one or a few adjacent mountaintops. Their timing of
diversification was highly congruent, supporting recent speciation
events within the past 600 thousand years. Extended Bayesian skyline
plots indicate that most populations have remained relatively stable in
size across evolutionary past, with recent growth after 0.15 My,
suggesting that the drastic changes found in previous studies on lowland
frog species were not shared by these montane taxa. These results are
consistent with the existence of a montane refugium in southern BAF,
allowing for species persistence under the climatic shifts experienced
along the BAF during the Quaternary.
